column1: Databases are crucial systems designed to store, organize, and manage data efficiently. They ensure data integrity, enable complex queries, and support multiple concurrent users. Here is an outline of their key features and a comparison between relational and NoSQL databases.
• Relational databases arrange data in structured tables with defined schemas.
• NoSQL databases offer flexible data models like documents, graphs, or key-value stores.
• Relational Databases: Feature ACID properties (Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability) for reliable transactions.
• NoSQL Databases: Often use BASE (Basically Available, Soft state, Eventually consistent) to support scalability.
• Databases implement security measures such as authentication, authorization, and encryption to ensure data protection.
• Support for multiple users to access and modify data simultaneously without compromising data consistency.
• Relational Databases: Typically scale vertically by enhancing existing server capacities.
• NoSQL Databases: Tend to scale horizontally by adding more servers, suitable for handling large datasets.
• Systems for regular data backups and efficient recovery to prevent data loss.
